name: Consumer Behavior

constraints.type_string: Fulfill all of the following requirements

long_desc: Marketing, in particular, begins and ends with the consumer from determining consumer needs to ensuring customer satisfaction. In this course, we will explore the most recent scientific research in marketing, psychology, and behavioral economics on judgment and decisionmaking. We will develop your ability to understand and influence what people want, how people decide what and when to buy, and whether people will be satisfied or dissatisfied with their decisions. These psychological insights are particularly useful for marketing strategy, brand positioning, and marketing communication decisions, but also yield insight into common biases in judgment and decision making, beyond marketing, to which you would otherwise fall prey.  Why people are willing to drive across town to save 5 on a tank of gasoline, for example, when they would not drive a minute to save 5 on a refrigerator. We will discuss some of these applications in class.  In addition, we will examine the methodology of market research specific to consumer behavior to build the tools you will need to interpret and base decisions on it. This course may use thirdparty course material that is not available for individual purchase from the publisher.   If so, the thirdparty course material will be secured and provided by the Tepper School to students enrolled in the course, and students enrolled in the course will be required to pay to the University the associated additional course materials fee for the thirdparty course material provided.   The amount of the course materials fee is dependent on the Universitys cost of the particular materials provided, and typically ranges from 13 to 75.

custom_fields.goals: Students who take this course seriously will be able to Obtain a greater understanding of consumer psychology and behavior Start to apply methodologies, findings, and theories in consumer behavior Develop, design, and execute a research project related to consumer behavior
custom_fields.key_topics: Consumer psychology; consumer decision making; consumer behavior; consumer research methods; consumer forecasting; consumer heuristics & biases; consumer mental accounting; the roles of emotions & intuitions in consumer choice; the roles of beliefs & expectations in consumer choice; persuasion & influence on consumer behavior; personal branding & first impressions; consumer ethics; behavioral pricing & consumer price perception.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Students should be familiar with Excel, writing papers, and giving presentations in class.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
Student grades will be based on:
- Class participation (quantity and quality of comments & discussion)
- Homework assignments (both papers and data-analysis problems)
- Midterm exam
- Final group presentation & paper
custom_fields.relevance: Consumer behavior is central to marketing. This course will examine key aspects of consumer behavior, judgment, and decision-making, and how these impact marketing. This course will also teach students to understand, and apply, key methodologies in consumer research.
custom_fields.learning_resources:
- Course canvas site
- Lecture slides
- Syllabus
- Course readings
- Data for homework assignments
- Solutions to forecasting assignment
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Homework assignments; a final group project for which student teams will need to meet regularly outside of class; studying for the midterm.
